statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: All-Star teammates Stephon Marbury and Shawn Marion scored 36 points apiece and the Phoenix Suns escaped with a 115-111 victory over the Chicago Bulls in overtime Monday night.
article.headline: Bulls give Suns a good run in Phoenix
article.linkText: Suns need Marbury and Marion's best to nip Bulls
article.story:
PHOENIX (AP) -- All-Star performances by Stephon Marbury and Shawn Marion enabled the Phoenix Suns to avoid an embarrassing pratfall against the Chicago Bulls on Monday night.
Marion

Marbury

Marbury and Marion -- both headed to the All-Star game Sunday in Atlanta -- scored 36 points apiece as the Suns escaped with a 115-111 overtime victory. "We stepped up big tonight and got a big win,'' Marion said. "It was a rough one, but we got it.'' Marbury, who also had nine assists, scored six in overtime, including consecutive drives to the basket that put Phoenix ahead 111-108 with 1:30 to play. His two free throws with 1.8 seconds left sealed the victory. "Man, that was a tough game,'' Marbury said. "They were making plays all day. Jalen Rose was playing great. But we just continued to play. We didn't show any quit.'' Marion sank a 3-pointer with 19.4 seconds left in regulation to help send the game to overtime after Phoenix trailed most of the night. "I didn't think I was going to be that wide open,'' Marion said, "but, hey, it worked.'' His two free throws with 19.9 seconds left in overtime put Phoenix ahead 113-109. Rose scored 28 points, but his streak of consecutive free throws made ended at 33 when he missed one of two with 9.1 seconds to play to leave the game tied at 105. "This game is humbling that way,'' Rose said. "You go up there and you shoot the same way and sometimes they go in and sometimes they don't. But being a great free-throw shooter, I expect to make every one, especially one at that critical point of the game.'' Donyell Marshall had 23 points and matched his season high with 18 rebounds as the Bulls barely fell short in their bid for a third road victory in 26 tries this season. Bo Outlaw added a season-high 16 points for Phoenix. Jay Williams' three-point play put Chicago up 108-105 early in overtime, but Joe Johnson's 18-footer cut the lead to 108-107. Marbury's drive put Phoenix ahead for good, 109-108, with 2:13 to play. After Marshall was called for an offensive foul, Marbury's floater bounced in and it was 111-108 with 1:30 to go. Williams made one of two free throws to cut it to 111-109 with 28.1 seconds left, then Marion's two free throws made it 113-109. Marion inadvertently tipped in Rose's miss to cut it to 113-111, then Marbury was fouled and put the game away. "It's just very disappointing that after all that work, all that effort, it just goes to waste,'' Bulls coach Bill Cartwright said, "because we can't get a stop.'' Marion's 3-pointer with 19.4 seconds to play gave the Suns their only lead of the fourth quarter, 105-104. After Rose made one of two free throws, Marbury's long 3-pointer at the regulation buzzer fell short. Chicago led 100-94 on Williams' 3-pointer with 2:32 to play in regulation. Marion made two free throws with 2:25 to go to cut it to 100-96. When Johnson missed the second of two free throws, Amare Stoudemire grabbed the offensive rebound, was fouled by Corie Blount and made both free throws to make it 100-99 with 1:30 to go. Rose made two free throws with 1:11 to play and Chicago led 102-99. Marbury's three-point play on a drive tied it at 102, then Marshall's rebound basket gave the Bulls a 104-102 lead with 27.9 seconds to play. Marion scored 23 and Marbury 20 in the second half and overtime. Suns coach Frank Johnson said he challenged the two as they came onto the court after the break. "I said, `You know, you guys are the leaders,''' Johnson said. "`Step up.''' The Bulls were up by as many as 11 in the third quarter. Their 82-79 lead after three quarters marked just the second time this season they have been ahead entering the fourth on the road.

Game notes
Chicago shot 67 percent in the first quarter. ... Phoenix is 20-4 at home. ... Stoudemire, who shot just 2-of-12, was named NBA rookie of the month for January. ... Chicago concludes its five-game trip Tuesday night in Denver. ... The Suns go into the All-Star break on a three-game winning streak.
